A number of researchers still believe nicotine replacement can help pregnant smokers.

For example, that big study in the U.K., it turns out only 7 percent of the women who got nicotine patches actually used them for more than a month, the way they were supposed to.
Oncken says her own study of nicotine gum showed a more positive effect.
What we found is that it helped women reduce their smoking, but not actually quit.
And Oncken says there's evidence that reduction in smoking helped protect the fetus.
It actually lowered nicotine exposure in our sample; and we had improvements, mainly birth weight and gestational age.
Oncken says when moms use nicotine replacement and smoke less, their babies are getting lower doses of toxins such as carbon monoxide, which can damage fetal brain cells.
And there's other things that could be neurotoxic, such as lead.
There's arsenic; there's a lot of bad things in cigarettes.
So when you look at the whole of it, if you could help somebody quit smoking, it's not just the nicotine, it's many other harmful chemicals.
Oncken says in her own practice, she first advises pregnant smokers to quit without using nicotine replacement therapy.
